Name: propylene production, from propane dehydrogenation | hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals
Description: There are several proceseses explored commercially, this dataset describes the Oleflex process. The processes are distinguished mainly based on their catalyst use and regeneration. Propane dehydrogenation processes are highly selective, overall yields of propylene from propane up to 90 % are claimed.;The propane feed is admitted to a moving-bed catalytic reactor. In a continuous process, the dehydrogenation catalyst circulates through the reaction vessel before passing to a separate regeneration vessel where coke is removed from the surface of the catalyst by combustion in air. The regenerated catalyst is returned to the first reactor.;Propene is recovered by conventional deethanizer – depropanizer splitting.;An overall selectivity for propene of 89 – 91% is claimed.;The chemical reaction of the reaction is:;C3H8 --> C3H6 + H2;The reaction is catalysed by a platinum-based catalyst, due to lack of data the catalyst was neglected.;References:;Eisele P.,Killpack R. (2011): Propene, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemisty, Wiley-VCH.;Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.
